questions.text: All of the following are morphological features of Papillary thyroid carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Nuclei shows fine dispersed chromatin and not smudged chromatin. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that exhibits distinct microscopic features, including:

  1. Papillae: Finger-like projections of tumor cells supported by a fibrovascular core.
  2. Ground-glass nuclei: Enlarged, pale, and clear nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin with a characteristic "Orphan Annie eye" appearance.
  3. Nuclear grooves and pseudo inclusions: Deep grooves and pseudoinclusions (invaginations) in the nuclear membrane.
  4. Psammoma bodies: Small, round, laminated calcifications (often seen in the papillae).
  5. Multinucleation: Presence of multiple nuclei within a single cell.
  6. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions: Cytoplasmic material within the nucleus.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1088.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. Laboratory tests reveal elevated TSH (12 mU/L) and anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies. Microscopic examination reveals epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm (Hurthle cells). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition characterized by elevated TSH and anti-TPO antibodies, leading to hypothyroidism.

  • Hurthle cells, which represent a metaplastic response of normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium is characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis.

B. Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition causing

C. De Quervain thyroiditis, also known as subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, is a rare inflammatory thyroid disorder. Thyroid function tests (TFTs) may show hyperthyroidism initially, followed by hypothyroidism.

D. Subclinical hypothyroidism has normal anti-TPO antibodies.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1079.

questions.text: What is the most common manifestation of Wermer syndrome?
questions.solution:
A, B & C: All are features of Wermer syndrome but the most common manifestation is option A, Primary hyperparathyroidism.

Option D: Medullary carcinoma is not a feature of Wermer syndrome.

Wermer syndrome is also known as MEN-1 syndrome.

  • MEN syndromes are group of inherited diseases resulting in proliferative lesion (hyperplasia, adenomas and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Here are several types of MEN syndromes, including:

  1. MEN1 (Wermer syndrome):
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia, primary hyperparathyroidism is most common of all.
    • Pituitary tumors
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
  2. MEN2A (Sipple syndrome):
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia
  3. MEN2B (Gorlin syndrome):
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Mucosal neuromas
    • Marfanoid habitus
  4. MEN4:
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia
    • Pituitary tumors
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
    • Adrenal tumors

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1129.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with:
Progressive azotemia
Proteinuria (3.8 g/day)
Hypertension
Kidney biopsy shows:

  • Nodular glomerulosclerosis with laminated fibrin caps
  • Mesangial matrix expansion
  • Tubular atrophy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. The patient's long-standing diabetes, progressive azotemia, proteinuria, and characteristic kidney biopsy findings (nodular glomerulosclerosis with laminated fibrin caps, mesangial matrix expansion, and tubular atrophy) are diagnostic of diabetic nephropathy, specifically Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.
  2. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a kidney disorder characterized by:
    • Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)
    • Proliferation of mesangial cells and matrix
    • Deposition of immune complexes and complement factors in the GBM
  3. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a kidney disease characterized by:
    • Scarring (sclerosis) of glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidney
    • Focal: Affects some glomeruli, not all Segmental: Affects parts of individual glomeruli
  4. IgA Nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1111.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with Paroxysmal hypertension, Headaches, Sweating, Weight loss ,Plasma catecholamines: 10x upper limit of normal
Imaging reveals a 4 cm adrenal mass
Adrenal gland biopsy shows:
Spindle-shaped cells with basophilic cytoplasm
Nuclear palisading
Sustentacular cells present
Immunohistochemistry: positive for S-100 protein and chromogranin A
Which of the following is the characteristic pattern can be seen microscopically?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms, elevated plasma catecholamines, and adrenal mass are suggestive of
  • The biopsy findings of spindle-shaped cells with basophilic cytoplasm, nuclear palisading, along with sustentacular cells and positive immunohistochemistry for S-100 protein and chromogranin A, confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

Option D. "Zellballen" pattern is a characteristic feature of pheochromocytoma, where the cells are arranged in clusters or "balls" surrounded by sustentacular cells.



  1. Chicken wire pattern is formed by the arrangement of blood vessels or endothelial cells in a mesh-like or net-like configuration, reminiscent of chicken wire. It's an important diagnostic clue for vascular tumors, especially hemangiomas and hemangioendotheliomas.
  2. Fried egg pattern is formed by the arrangement of tumor cells, with the central zone representing the tumor cells' cytoplasm and the surrounding clear area representing the glycogen-rich cytoplasm. Typically seen in Oligodendrogliomas, germinomas etc.
  3. Papillary pattern is formed by the arrangement of tumor cells in a papilla-like configuration, often with a central blood vessel or connective tissue core. Subtypes of papillary pattern include:
    • True papillae: finger-like projections with a central fibrovascular core
    • Pseudopapillae: papillary-like structures without a central fibrovascular core
    • Micropapillae: small, tiny papillae

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:1128.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for testicular biopsy?
questions.solution:
C. Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in cases of active testicular infection, as it may spread the infection or lead to abscess formation.

  • The other options are not absolute contraindications, and biopsy may still be performed with caution and appropriate management.
  • Infertility is most common indication for testicular biopsy.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 967.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with a painless testicular mass. Ultrasound reveals a solid, heterogeneous tumor. Histopathological examination shows:
Papillary and glandular patterns
Hyaline droplets and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) positivity
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image shown above is of Schiller duval body, which resembles endodermal sinuses, consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.


B. Papillary and glandular pattern, elevated AFP level, age of the patient and an image of Schiller Duval body lead to a diagnosis of prepubertal yolk sac tumor.

Option A: Embryonal carcinoma : Embryonal carcinoma is a relatively uncommon type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumor that occurs in the ovaries and testes. Micrograph of an embryonal carcinoma showing its typical features - prominent nucleoli, marked nuclear atypia, necrosis, and nuclear overlap.


Option C: Teratoma: A teratoma is a tumor made up of several types of tissue, such as hair, muscle, teeth, or bone.


Option D: Leydig cell tumor: Due to excess testosterone secreted by the tumor, one-third of female patients present with a recent history of progressive masculinization. Masculinization is preceded by anovulation, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and defeminization. Additional signs include acne and hirsutism, voice deepening, clitoromegaly, temporal hair recession, and an increase in musculature. Serum testosterone level is high.


Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:972.

choices.text: Irregular, haphazardly arranged glands with angulated contours
Small, uniform glands with rounded contours and a "double-layer" arrangement of cells
Glands with a "single-layer" arrangement of cells and prominent nucleoli
Glands with squamous metaplasia and keratinization

questions.text: Which of the following histological features is characteristic of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
• Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is characterized by an increase in the number of prostatic glands and stroma, leading to an enlargement of the prostate gland.
  • The glands in BPH are typically small, uniform, and have rounded contours, with a "double-layer" arrangement of cells (inner luminal cells and outer basal cells).

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 967.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with an Ovarian mass
Elevated inhibin and CA-125 levels
Large amounts of Estrogen
Ovarian biopsy shows:

  • Small, distinctive, gland like structures filled with an acidophilic material (call exner body)
  • Cuboidal to polygonal cells grow in anastomosing cords, and sheets.
  • Immunohistochemistry: positive for inhibin and vimentin.
Which is the mass most likely?
questions.solution:
The patient's elevated inhibin and CA-125 levels, and ovarian biopsy findings of Small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material (Call-Exner bodies) characteristic of granulosa cell tumor. The positive immunohistochemistry for inhibin and vimentin further supports this diagnosis.

Options B,C and D doesn't present with Call Exner bodies.


Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:1026.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents with a pelvic mass. The resected tumor shows: A solid and cystic mass with multiple nodules
On Microscopy, the tumor contains:

  • Mature cartilage and bone
  • Gastrointestinal epithelium with villi and goblet cells
  • Respiratory epithelium with cilia and mucous glands
  • Hair follicles
  • Immunohistochemistry: positive for AE1/AE3, SALL4, and PLAP
questions.solution:
• The presence of mature tissues (cartilage, bone, gastrointestinal epithelium, and respiratory epithelium, hair follicles) characteristic of dermoid cyst (mature teratoma.)
  • The positive immunohistochemistry for AE1/AE3, SALL4, and PLAP further supports this diagnosis.

Options B,C and D are incorrect.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1023.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with Uterine tumor, Beta-hCG 100,000 IU/L, No fetal parts. Histology shows Sheets of cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast, Absence of villi. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. The patient's clinical presentation and histological findings are characteristic of choriocarcinoma:
    1. Uterine tumor: Choriocarcinoma typically arises in the uterus.
    2. Beta-hCG 100,000 IU/L: Elevated beta-hCG is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma.
    3. No fetal parts: Choriocarcinoma is a trophoblastic neoplasm without fetal tissue.
    4. Histology:
      • Sheets of cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast: Diagnostic feature of choriocarcinoma.
      • Absence of villi: Distinguishes choriocarcinoma from hydatidiform mole.
  2. Hydatidiform mole:
    • Characterized by villi with hydropic degeneration.
    • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.
  3. Placental site trophoblastic tumor:
    • Arises from placental bed trophoblasts.
    • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.
  4. Invasive mole:
    • Characterized by villi invading myometrium.
    • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 972.

questions.text: The most common site of distant metastasis for prostatic adenocarcinoma is:
questions.solution:
C. Bones: Most common site for distant metastasis, especially in prostate cancer.

A. Lungs: Less common site for prostate cancer metastasis.

B. Liver: Common site for metastasis, especially in advanced disease.

D. Brain: Rare site for prostate cancer metastasis.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:979.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman undergoes oophorectomy for a 15 cm ovarian mass. Histology shows:
Mucinous adenocarcinoma
Signet ring cell morphology
Positive for PAX8
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Krukenberg tumors are metastatic tumors to the ovaries, typically from gastric or breast carcinoma.
  • Characterized by signet ring cell morphology and stromal fibrosis.
  • Positive for PAX8, supporting ovarian origin.
  • Clinical presentation and histology are consistent with metastatic disease.

Option A. Primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma

  • Primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas are aggressive and often present at advanced stage.
  • Typically, have a complex papillary architecture and high-grade nuclear atypia.
  • May not always exhibit signet ring cell morphology.

Option B. Metastatic gastric carcinoma

  • Gastric carcinomas can metastasize to the ovaries and exhibit signet ring cell morphology.
  • Typically, have a diffuse or infiltrative growth pattern.
  • Usually, are positive for CK7 and negative for PAX8.

Option C. Metastatic colorectal carcinoma

  • Colorectal carcinomas can metastasize to the ovaries but typically do not exhibit signet ring cell morphology.
  • Usually, have a glandular or cribriform
  • Typically, are positive for CK20 and negative for PAX8.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1021.

choices.text: Viral infection leading to thyroid inflammation

questions.text: De Quervain thyroiditis is characterized by:
questions.solution:
• De Quervain thyroiditis is a non-neoplastic inflammatory condition
  • Results from viral infection triggering an immune response.
  • Involves activation of T-cells and macrophages.
  • Leads to thyroid follicle destruction and release of pre-formed thyroid hormones.

Histological features:

  • Granulomas with giant cells and epithelioid cells.
  • Lymphocytic infiltration.
  • Thyroid follicle destruction.

Clinical implications:

  • Thyrotoxicosis due to release of pre-formed thyroid hormones.
  • Thyroid tenderness and pain.
  • Elevated ESR and CRP.
  1. Autoimmune destruction of thyroid tissue characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  2. Viral infection leading to thyroid inflammation: Partially correct. Viral infections can trigger De Quervain thyroiditis, but this option doesn't fully describe the condition.
  3. Neoplastic transformation of thyroid cells

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1080.

choices.text: Severe depletion of B cells in islets

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital in an obtunded condition. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. She seems to be dehydrated and has poor skin turgor. Her serum glucose level is 872 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 4+ glucosuria, but no ketones, protein, or blood. Which of the following factors is most important in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus with hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma.
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency, leading to hyperglycemia.
  • In type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, there is a decrease in plasma insulin or a relative lack of insulin, but there is still enough to prevent ketosis.

B. The fundamental defect is insulin resistance.

  • The resulting hyperglycemia tends to produce polyuria, leading to dehydration, which increases the serum glucose level further.
  • If enough fluids are not ingested, dehydration drives the serum glucose to very high levels.

Option A: The HLA-DR3/HLA-DR4 genotype is a predisposing factor for type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Option C: Autoimmune insulitis typically affects younger individuals.

  • Often presents with ketosis.
  • Autoimmune insulitis, also known as autoimmune pancreatitis or type 1c diabetes, is a rare form of diabetes characterized by autoimmune inflammation of the pancreas, specifically targeting the insulin-producing beta cells.

Option D. Severe loss of ß cells is a feature of autoimmune, or type 1, diabetes mellitus.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1104.
